Biden Advises Americans Who Can't Afford Gasoline to Buy an EV

After test driving a $112,595 electric Hummer pickup President Joe Biden told Americans: "For the hundreds of thousands of folks who bought one of those electric cars, they’re going to save $800 to $1,000 in fuel costs this year." The president appeared frustrated that some Americans continue blaming his environmental agenda for higher gas prices, dismissing it as a “myth.” “My effort to combat climate change is not raising the price of gas, what it’s doing is increasing the availability of jobs,” he insisted, claiming that government subsidies for green energy and electric cars would only help Americans get jobs and save more money.

Less than a month after joining almost 200 countries in a pledge to fight climate change at COP26 Japan is putting the brakes on fossil-fuel divestment. Government officials have been quietly urging trading houses, refiners, and utilities to slow down their move away from fossil fuels, and even encouraging new investments in oil-and-gas projects. The officials are concerned about the long-term supply of traditional fuels as the world doubles down on renewable energy. The import-dependent nation wants to avoid a potential shortage of fuel this winter, as well as during future cold spells, after a deficit last year sparked fears of nationwide blackouts.

Japan’s Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry declined to comment directly on whether it is encouraging industries to boost investment in upstream energy supply, and instead pointed to a strategic energy plan approved by the cabinet on October 22. That plan says, “no compromise is acceptable to ensure energy security, and it is the obligation of a nation to continue securing necessary resources.” That latest strategy calls for the share of oil and natural gas produced either domestically or under the control of Japanese enterprises overseas to increase from 34.7% in fiscal year 2019 to more than 60% in 2040.

Offshore wind is the new darling of the European oil industry as the biggest names in petroleum scrap it out in western Europe and North America. Competition for prime acreage is rife, resulting in some questionable bids. BP faced accusations that it overpaid in the UK’s latest leasing round. There is a similar scramble to secure 15-year fixed returns enshrined in a Contract for Difference (CfD) or similarly bankable support instrument.

CfD auctions frequently clear at the minimum price, as occurred at a recent 1 GW Danish tender that saw companies draw lots in a tie-break. This result was hailed as historic, which it undoubtedly is, since the (un)lucky winner – RWE – will pay the Danish state DKK 2.8 billion (€376 million) by 2028 and pick up the tab for export cables and grid connection. Wind turbine makers, facing materials inflation and labour constraints, have warned that turbine costs can't keep falling forever.

Unlike traditional petroleum investments, offshore wind cannot reliably generate double-digit returns, and quickly enough to support a high rate of reinvestment in new projects and sustain dividends sufficient to attract new capital. The calculus seems to be that taking on projects with poor economics is a price worth paying for polluting companies desperate to burnish their ESG credentials and renew their social license to operate.

Steven E. Koonin, former US policy advisor to the Obama administration and author of the best-seller Unsettled: What Climate Science Tells Us, What It Doesn’t, and Why It Matters, delivered the Global Warming Policy Foundation’s 2021 Annual Lecture, which the Conservative Woman presents in a 43-minute video. What Prof. Koonin had done in his book is translate the IPCC's reports into plain English, which enrages climate activists. Everything in the book is from the official reports or peer reviewed literature.

All the politicians' and officials' warnings of climate disaster/crisis/catastrophe, existential threat, code red, etc., start with the IPCC assessment reports, was well as various national assessments. However, none of the politicians and officials making these warnings have ever read the reports, and none of the reports support the warnings. Misrepresenting science to persuade, rather than inform, usurps the right of the public to make fully informed decisions, distracts from more urgent needs, tarnishes science, and depresses young people. Prof. Koonin's recommended course going forward:
• Cancel the "climate crisis" but acknowledge the task/challenge of reducing human influences.
• Use better observations and understanding of the climate.
• Develop and demonstrate emissions-light technology (nuclear, grid storage and management, batteries, and non-carbon chemical fuels.

In the November 2021 edition of Scientific American, and referring to publication of the IPCC's AR6 report by its Working Group 1, Naomi Oreskes wrote: "After all, if human-made warming is as unequivocal as these scientists insist, then why do we need more reports to tell us the same thing? Closing WG1 would answer that question and would allow climate scientists to refocus on basic science, which is, after all, what most of them are trained to do. And it would encourage public and policy attention to shift to solving the problem."

This didn’t sit well with two establishment physicists (Sabine Hossenfelder and Tim Palmer) who objected to Mr. Oreskes' recommendation, writing a response in Scientific American agreeing that, while the scientific basis of long-term global trends is settled, current generation climate models are crude representations of the climate's complex dynamics. Current climate models can't represent cloud systems using physical laws, relying instead on simplified empirical formulas. As a result, current climate models can't simulate extreme weather events and attribute their cause to climate change. The physicists want the world to create an international centre for climate modelling modelled on CERN.

This Watts Up With That? story contains a 43-minute video, No Certain Doom: On the Accuracy of Projected Global Average Surface Air Temperatures, in which WUWT's Dr. Pat Frank explains his concerns with climate models and clouds. In particular, he shows that the typical shaded areas shown on either side of a plot of projected mean temperatures represent the model's (or models') internal divergence or precision, typically in a range of 5% to 95%, or 1.64 standard deviations. They say nothing about the model's reliability or accuracy. According to Dr Frank the models have an average ±4 W/m2 annual cloud error that propagates in the stepwise projections of future climate, and these accumulate to total errors of ±13°C by 2100 (25:30 in the video), which are far outside any physical possibility. Thus, even the most advanced climate models are making errors so large (greater than any greenhouse gas signal) that their temperature projections are meaningless.

The Real Threat to Banks Isn't from Climate Change, It's from Bankers

Michael Schellenberger, author of Apocalypse Never: Why Environmentalism Hurts Us All, notes that over the past two years, some of the world's most powerful and influential bankers and investors have argued that climate change poses a grave threat to financial markets, and nations must switch from fossil fuels to renewables. Former Bank of England chief Mark Carney created the Glasgow Financial Alliance, or GFANZ, with Michael Bloomberg to put global finance on a trajectory that ultimately leaves high-carbon assets facing a much bleaker future. Three of the largest donors to climate change causes are billionaire financial titans Michael Bloomberg, George Soros, and Tom Steyer, all of whom have significant investments in both renewables and fossil fuels.

However, a new staff report from the New York Federal Reserve Bank, How Bad Are Weather Disasters for Banks?, found that weather disasters over the past quarter century had insignificant or small effects on US banks' performance. In fact, disasters are actually good for banks, since they increase demand for loans. The larger a bank’s exposure to natural disasters, the larger its profits.

Mr. Nordhaus is the founder and executive director of the Breakthrough Institute, a research centre focused on technological solutions to environmental challenges. In this article for The Economist he argues that, by exaggerations and impractical demands, the climate movement undermines its cause and brings suffering to everyone. Mr. Nordhaus notes that global deaths from climate-related disasters are at an all-time low, as is people's vulnerability to extreme weather — thanks to economic growth and development. International efforts slow the growth in emissions appear to be working to bring the goal of 2°C within reach. However, the global climate-industrial complex — a nexus of campaigners, green charities and sustainable-business practitioners who are aided, abetted, and amplified by their ideologically (and socially) aligned handmaidens in academia and stenographers in media — has simply moved the goalposts for climate stabilization, from 2°C to 1.5°C warming.

The 1.5°C target is implausible and arbitrary. It would require rebuilding the entire global economy within a decade. To appease influential domestic environmental constituencies, Western political leaders have made far-reaching but non-binding commitments to cut emissions that they almost certainly cannot keep. When Western leaders are caught between the impossible demands of activists and domestic political realities, it is the poor, not the activist class that ends up paying for it.

CLINTEL's World Climate Declaration, its president and other CLINTEL ambassadors were featured prominently on Russian TV in a popular program on current events. Staff at CLINTEL were surprised at not having been approached by the program Vesti nedeli (Вести недели — News of the week) but pleased that Russia doesn't blindly follow western media's panic stories about climate. The title of the program was "Warming of the Earth as a new religion that can’t be talked about." There is an eight-minute video with Russian dialog and a transcript of the broadcast in English.

The program suggests looking not at the "green" totalitarian sect of Greta Thunberg but to serious scientists for whom it is clear that the Sun is the deciding factor of the Earth's climate. It was even hotter before humans came along, and we are still within the boundaries of cyclical warming and cooling of the past thousand years.

At COP26 a group of auto manufacturers including General Motors, Volvo, Ford and Mercedes-Benz declared that they would "work towards" all sales of new cars and vans being zero emission globally by 2040, and no later than 2035 in “leading markets.” Achieving that target would mean almost 8,400 GWh of lithium-ion battery production, requiring over 7 million tonnes of lithium annually, which is 17 times the 2021 amount. According to Simon Moores, CEO of Benchmark Mineral Intelligence, there is insufficient investment into raw material supply to meet battery demand in 2030 let alone 2040, and lithium demand is growing at three times that of lithium supply. It would also require over 5 million tonnes of nickel sulphate, which is 19 times the 2021 production. Building a battery factory takes two years, but a new lithium mine needs at least five.

However, while large countries such as India signed the declaration, China, Japan, and the US abstained, as did carmakers Volkswagen, Toyota, and Nissan-Renault.

Tony Blair Institute: New 1.2 GW Offshore Wind Farm Every 10 Weeks to Hit Net Zero

The Tony Blair Institute has calculated that to meet the legally-binding net zero target by 2050, the UK must build the equivalent of a 1.2 GW offshore wind farm every 10 weeks for the next 20 years. According to the Dogger Bank Wind Farm website, their 1.2 GW wind farm cost £3 billion (USD $4 billion). The Dogger Bank wind farm is over 100 km from shore and doesn't have any battery backup.

The Net Zero Watch Guide to Decarbonizing Your Life

In view of COP26 and the failure of world leaders to stop climate change, Net Zero Watch has prepared a humorous guide for individuals to save the planet from the climate change emergency extinction apocalypse. Suggestions include blaming every unpleasant seasonal weather event on climate change, preparing for winter by switching to heat pumps for home heating, switching to a green energy supplier, getting a green job, limiting your family, and capturing your own carbon.

In this 6-minute video NetZero Watch's Benny Peiser is interviewed by talkRADIO's Julia Hartley-Brewer about COP26 and whether it will end with a deal that makes any difference. Dr. Peiser assures her that COPs always end with a deal that mainly says that everybody will be very good, will work together and will meet again next year. Every time the same pantomime: it's always one minute before Armageddon, the last chance.

The West became wealthy using fossil fuels is now telling the developing world to phase them out, with the never-met promise of $100 billion/year. CO emissions will continue to go up and most of the world will not significantly decarbonize. They will not believe what Joe Biden tells them because the next US president could repudiate Mr. Biden's promises. Climate will continue to change, regardless of the number of wind turbines built.

COP26 - Where Democracy and Debate Went Up in Flames

Sigmundur Davið Gunnlaugsson, a former prime minister of Iceland, attended COP26 as part of the Icelandic delegation. Having attended the Paris COP21 in 2015, this was Mr. Gunnlaugsson's second COP. After Paris he realized that he should have been more critical and questioned the groupthink. At Paris, everything had been decided before he arrived, and COP21 was all about solidarity and getting every country on the globe to sign up.

On the way to COP26 Mr. Gunnlaugsson was presented with a draft declaration from the Inter-Parliamentary Union, a global organization of national parliaments. According to this declaration, CO emissions don't just affect the weather, but also impact equality, social justice, global food security and almost every issue of concern. At the COP there was little scope for debate on this declaration, with the day-long agenda being taken up with "advocacy sessions", "inspirational talks" and "expert opinion." The parliamentarians were told that if they wanted to make a point, they should have sent an email, and thus the document was adopted.

After 26 COP Meetings Coal, Oil and Gas Give Us 80% of the Energy on Earth

Jo Nova's blog shows a plot of global primary energy consumption by source from 1800 to 2019. Since 1850 traditional biomass has been steady at around 11,000 TWh/year, while coal, oil and natural gas have grown from zero to 137,000 TWh/year of the 173,000 TWh/year total for 2019. After three decades of effort, 26 COPs, six IPCC reports and installation of 400,000 wind turbines, the energy supplied by the big renewable energy transition still amounts to about 5% of total energy production.

The EU's climate chief Frans Timmermans gave a clear signal that the bloc is considering a role for natural gas under its rulebook for green investments. An exit from coal for some member states like Poland will require an "intermediary stage" using natural gas. The EU's rulebook, or taxonomy regulation, has three categories of suitable investments: "green" "enabling" and "transition", with the last including natural gas. Environmental groups criticized this inclusion, as well as the potential addition of nuclear energy.

China Mocks Joe Biden's Powerlessness at COP26 – The US Turns the Other Cheek

The Global Times is published under the auspices of the Chinese Communist Party's People's Daily newspaper, commenting on international issues from a nationalistic perspective. In this editorial it mocked US President Joe Biden for his remarks during the leaders' action and solidarity event at the start of COP26: "I guess I shouldn't apologize, but I do apologize for the fact the US, under the last administration, pulled out of the Paris accord."

Global Times' assessment of Mr. Biden's apology: "What a "noble" apology, which made Biden seem like he cares about climate change, but also how hypocritical and powerless he is. Unlike what Biden may have expected, the apology triggered ridicule. Quite a few netizens, including those from the US, claimed they cannot wait until 2024 when the Republican Party, or even Donald Trump himself, apologizes for Biden's apology. Most people believe this was hardly an apology, but a slap in the face of his predecessor, a move to pin all the blame on Trump. This is not about how sorry Biden is. He was making a show and bringing US political infighting to the global arena."

Nine days after the Global Times piece, the US and Chinese climate envoys at Glasgow issued a statement declaring climate change to be an existential crisis and demanding cooperation between the two countries.

What Net Zero Will Cost You

Prior to the start of COP26 British actor Lawrence Fox made this seven-minute video on net-zero and the bypassing of democracy. Successive UK governments have sought to take a leading role at COPs in persuading other governments to a global emissions-reduction deal, in the hope that the rest of the world will follow Britain's lead in living without fossil fuels. Since 2008 the UK politicians have adopted the net-zero agenda without explaining to the public what the resulting commitments mean to them. Instead, they have promised that the climate policies will create jobs, economic growth, and equality.

At first these policies affected large industries and electrical generation, and so people didn't notice them. Now the politicians are proposing abolition of the gas boiler for home heating and hot water, in favour of air-sourced heat pumps (much more expensive, less effective and requiring upgrading of building insulation.) Sales of new petrol and diesel cars will be banned, forcing low-income drivers out of their vehicles. Cost of all this: £3 trillion. Rather than creating new jobs and industries, these policies will destroy them. UK manufacturers of wind turbines, unable to afford high energy costs, are being forced to buy components from China. Failure to plan for times without wind and global gas supply shortages forced closing of food manufacturing plants.

UK governments expected that they would not have to seek the consent of voters for their climate policies. Instead, they hoped to take authority from global agreements and resulting institutions, thereby binding government policy. In this way the UK government has sought to bypass democracy. Any critics of this process have been banned from the media. The result of the net-zero ideological agenda will be rising energy bills, more shutdown of industry, more jobs lost, freedoms like driving and flying made unaffordable, forced changes in diet.

The cost of net zero? Everything.

The Canadian Energy Centre has issued this commentary about how expensive renewables are creating energy poverty in Europe. In Europe people pay twice for generated electricity: once for the sunk costs of existing fossil-fuel and nuclear plants, and again for renewable-energy generation. When wind and solar power are not available, nations are chasing the same natural gas and coal, pushing those fuel prices higher.

Energy poverty occurs when citizens are too poor to pay their utility bills on time and/or keep their homes warm. Research by U. of Manchester professor Stefan Bouzarovski, chair of the energy poverty network Engager, found that 80 million European households were already struggling to keep their homes warm before the pandemic and 12 million are in arrears on their utility bills.

The CEC notes that the response of some European countries was to subsidize utility bills, as Ontario did to mask the expense of past government policy, shifting the burden of high power prices from the "consumer pocket" to the "taxpayer pocket." In Europe and the UK, "transitioning" from fossil fuels has resulted in their share of electricity production declining from 50% in 2000 to 26% in 2019, while renewables increased from 16% to 34% in the same period. When wind power dropped, coal was again used to prop up the UK power grid.

The CEC has published Energy Poverty in European Households: An Advance Lesson for Canadians, which examines the issue in detail.

Coal Keeps the Lights on at COP26

An embarrassment for the UK's failing renewable strategy: critically low wind power for November 2 resulted in extremely high power prices, with the two remaining coal units at Drax saving the day at a cost of £4,000/MWh. This is nearly 100 times the normal wholesale price before the current crisis started. During the day, wind reached a minimum of 1 GW, less than 5% of its capacity. The UK climate strategy is all but entirely committed to renewables, and it isn’t working.

Officials from Canada and around the world boarded over 400 private jets to attend COP26. According to the Scottish paper Daily Record, the flights will produce more CO than 1600 Scots emit in a year. On October 26, five days before the start of the conference, a Canadian military C17 Globemaster strategic airlift jet landed at Prestwick airport in Scotland. While at the COP, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a hard cap of Canada's oil and gas producers: "We’ll cap oil and gas sector emissions today and ensure they decrease tomorrow at a pace and scale needed to reach net-zero by 2050."

China Reaffirms Existing Climate Targets in Submission to UN ahead of COP26

Just days before the start of COP26 China reaffirmed an existing set of targets that was announced by president Xi Jinping in December 2020. Playing down diplomatic pressure for Beijing to update its plan, the latest submission states: “To address climate change is not at others’ request but on China’s own initiative.”? Analysis attribute the absence of new ambition to the power crunch caused by surging coal prices and supply constraints that have forced factories to curb production and left households without electricity.

On October 29 India rejected international pressure to announce a net-zero target. At COP26 it will emphasize climate justice and ask wealthier nations to transfer technology and finance needed to help developing countries deal with global warming.

One week ahead of COP26 Saudi Arabia submitted its updated nationally determined contribution under the Paris Agreement. A Climate Home News article claims that the kingdom will reach net zero by 2060, but that promise appears nowhere in the Saudi submission to the UNFCCC. This promises to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 278 million tonnes of CO eq annually by 2030, compared to 2019, more than double the previous NDC of 130 million tonnes. By 2030 the kingdom aims to generate around 50% of its electricity by renewables (solar PV, concentrated solar power, wind, geothermal, waste to energy and green hydrogen).

Crown prince Mohammed bin Salman announced he would invest 700 billion riyals ($187 billion) in climate action this decade and stressed that Saudi Arabia would continue producing oil and gas, "while preserving and reinforcing the kingdom’s leading role in the security and stability of global energy markets, with the availability and maturity of required technologies to manage and reduce emissions." There is no plan to reduce oil exports.

Australia pledged to reach net-zero emissions by mid-century without any major legislation restricting fossil fuels. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the country would lean on investments in renewable and other clean energy technologies to meet its target and not introduce taxes or other mandates to cut emissions. Details about the plan to reach net-zero are sparse, and Mr. Morrison indicated that he would reveal more at the United Nations’ climate change conference in Glasgow, which began on October 31.

Xi And Putin Leave COP26 Climate Alarmists in The Lurch

China's and Russia's presidents declined to appear at COP26, which could be a blow for Western climate alarmists. China's President Xi Jing Ping rules a country faced with power blackouts due to coal shortages and where the state bureaucracy is working to increase the production and importation of fossil fuels. There is no guarantee that China will achieve its promise of net zero by 2060. Russia's Vladimir Putin has increased his country's domination of natural gas and has ramped up its coal sector. Russia's deputy prime minister's realistic assessment of the world's energy needs: "The share of oil and gas in the world’s energy mix is set to drop from 85 percent to around 65-70 percent, not to 20-30 percent as some experts have forecast."

At the G20 meeting on October 31, Australia, India, China and Russia blocked efforts to call for an end to coal use. Diplomats from the UK and Europe had been pressing for a commitment by large economies to phase out coal, which is responsible for 44% of anthropogenic CO emissions.

Said the Australian prime minister: "We are not engaged in those sorts of mandates and bans. That's not the Australian government's policy, it won't be the Australian government's policy." China and India owe their membership in the G20 to their economic development fueled by coal and fear the cost of shifting their energy mix. Russia is also a big coal exporter.

Donor Countries Set to Reach $100 billion Climate Finance Target in 2023 – Three Years Late

COP26 president Alok Sharma asked the environment ministers of Germany and Canada to produce a Delivery Plan for the $100 billion/year in climate finance from 2020 onward that had been promised to developing nations. On October 25 Environment and Climate Change Canada announced that, based on recent pledges and an OECD analysis, there is confidence that the goal will be met in 2023, with more thereafter through to 2025. The COP26 Presidency has compiled a list of the 2021-25 climate finance commitments by 12 countries and the European Commission. Canada’s pledge is $5.3 billion over 2021-26, of which 40% will be in the form of grants.

COP26 and the Hubris of Our Political Overlords

Francis Menton's essay argues that, even if the annual COPs waste resources and have the potential to damage the world economy and well-being of people, it's still good to have them. There are no other comparable activities that put on such dramatic and widely viewed display of the immeasurable foolishness and hubris of our political overlords. The hundreds of global leaders at COP26 have no idea how the world's energy systems work but have come together to agree and order that those systems must be completely discarded and replaced.

Charts of nearly three decades of COPs and corresponding CO emissions and atmospheric concentrations show steady upward trends.

A new report from a Berlin-based think tank, the Hot or Cool Institute, shows that Canada is trailing behind a group of ten countries that the institute selected to represent a range of income levels. These countries, listed in descending order of per capita "average lifestyle carbon footprints" are: Canada, Finland, the UK, Japan, China, Turkey, South Africa, Brazil, India and Indonesia. In 2019 the average Canadian produced 14.2 tonnes of CO e, compared to 9.7 t in Finland and 8.5 t in the UK. The five components of these footprints are food, housing, transport, goods, and leisure & services. In Canada's case these components have respective carbon footprints (t) of 2.27, 3.05, 4.99, 2.51 and 1.39 (report, Annex B, Table B.2).

The report, 1.5-Degree Lifestyles: Towards a Fair Consumption Space for All, begins with the statement: "In a world with a limited and fast-shrinking carbon budget, coupled with vast inequalities, how do we allocate the remaining carbon allowance in a manner that is fair while drastically decreasing out footprints within a limited time frame to avoid irreversible ecological damage?" The report's authors aim for global lifestyle carbon footprints of 2.5 t by 2030, 1.4 t by 2040 and 0.7 t by 2050 (Summary for Policymakers, p.5). For Canada this means carbon footprint reductions of 82%, 90% and 95%, respectively.

After 31 municipal councils in Ontario called for phasing out natural gas generation by 2030, the province's Independent Electricity System Operator prepared a report on its feasibility and cost. The report, Decarbonization and Ontario's Electricity System: Assessing the impacts of phasing out natural gas generation by 2030, has some key findings:
• The phaseout would lead to blackouts, as electricity would not always be available when and where needed.
• There is no like-for-like replacement supply with the operating characteristics of gas generation.
• It would require more than $27 billion to install new sources of supply and upgrade transmission infrastructure, resulting in a $100 increase in the average monthly residential bill.
• Approving, building and upgrading the needed transmission and generation infrastructure could not be done within eight years.
• Year-round electricity supply would be needed from Quebec, which is unrealistic given that it is reliant on electricity imported from Ontario and other jurisdictions during the winter months.

The BBC has seen a “huge leak of documents”? revealing how countries pushed back against recommendations for action contained in the latest IPCC assessment report, AR6. These leaked documents are part of 32,000 submissions on a draft of the report from governments, companies and other interested parties made to the IPCC authors. The leaked documents were passed to Greenpeace’s UK team of investigative journalists, which then delivered them to the BBC. Among the pushbacks:
• An adviser to the Saudi oil ministry demands "phrases like 'the need for urgent and accelerated mitigation actions at all scales…' should be eliminated from the report".
• A senior Australian government official rejects the conclusion that closing coal-fired power plants is necessary.
• A senior scientist from India's Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research, which has strong links to the Indian government, warns coal is likely to remain the mainstay of energy production for decades because of what they describe as the "tremendous challenges" of providing affordable electricity.
• Brazil and Argentina, two of the biggest producers of beef products and animal feed crops in the world, argue strongly against evidence in the draft report that reducing meat consumption is necessary to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
• A significant number of Switzerland's comments are directed at amending parts of the report that argue developing countries will need support, particularly financial support, from rich countries to meet emission reduction targets.
• Several mostly eastern European countries argue the draft report should be more positive about the role nuclear power can play in meeting the UN's climate targets.

As Eric Worral argues in a WUWT essay: “Frankly I think national interest lobbyists should get out of the way and grant climate alarmists unfettered freedom to speak their minds. The sheer absurdity of alarmist positions, like demanding the world slash fossil fuel production in the middle of a northern hemisphere energy crisis, would do more to wreck the green climate charade than anything I could ever write.”?

To Strike a Climate Deal, Poor Nations Want Trillions from Rich Ones

At a July climate meeting in London, the South African environment minister presented a bill of $750 billion annually from the world's wealthiest countries to pay for the poorest ones to shift away from fossil fuels and protect themselves from global warming. US climate envoy John Kerry and other Western official met the demand with silence. As part of the Paris Agreement, the US, Europe and other wealthy nations committed to providing $100 billion/year in climate finance from 2020 to 2025 but have so far fallen short.

At COP26 in Glasgow developing nations are expected to demand a big increase in climate funding before signing on a deal to keep the climate targets of the Paris Agreement within reach. They face the task of raising living standards without burning fossil fuels as the US and other rich nations did for almost two centuries. They want most of the climate finance as government grants, not loans from private investors.

On October 18 Bolivia hosted a virtual meeting of ministers from a group of 24 emerging nations (the Like-Minded Developing Countries), including China, India, Egypt, Indonesia, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Vietnam. According to the resulting LMDC Ministerial Statement, the meeting's purpose "was to gather perspectives on the way forward" for COP26. The statement (part 4) accuses major developed countries of shifting the goal posts of the Paris Agreement by calling on all countries to adopt net-zero targets for 2050. The LMDCs claim that the new "goal" runs counter to the Agreement, is anti-equity and against climate justice as it will exacerbate existing inequities between developed and developing countries.

Instead, developed countries, that have historically overused their domestic carbon space and used those of developing countries, should "leave the remaining atmospheric space for the developmental rights of the developing world and aim for their full decarbonization within this decade." In short, the rich world should aim for net zero by 2030, not 2050.

Gripped by Energy Crisis, Europe Considers Breaking Climate Promises and Turning to Coal

At $134/MWh, the European benchmark price for natural gas is up nearly 600% in the past year and the EU is seeking more gas, and even coal, supply from Russia. The approaching winter will make access to fuel even more urgent. Newsweek spoke to three experts on this crisis. The Chair for European Energy and Climate Policy at the College of Europe said that current difficulties should encourage more investment in renewable energy.

An assistant professor of international relations at Webster Vienna Private University in Vienna, Austria pointed to the ideologically-inspired abandonment of nuclear energy in Germany and Sweden, arguing that a return to coal is more "sellable" than a return to nuclear. He said: "The turn away from fossil fuels was always based on the mirage that it would have no real-life consequences for the average European, or that they would not fully comprehend slowly rising energy prices as part of general inflation. With the risk of runaway inflation, however, people are becoming increasingly more sensitive to what their monthly bills consist of, and at some point, using fossil fuels and nuclear energy will be politically more expedient than clinging to climate change goals."

A professor at Yale Law School and former commissioner at the Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection wanted more incentives for cost-effective renewable energy. Since the public's willingness to pay a significant premium to avoid greenhouse gas emissions wanes as prices spike, policies need to focus not just on clean energy and renewable power but also on cheaper and more reliable electricity. Thus, the commitment to shut down nuclear plants before renewable energy was available at scale and competitive cost was a mistake.

Low wind speeds across much of Europe during the summer led to a shortage of power on the grid and a consequent spike in prices — something that usually happens in winter when demand is high. One of the biggest factors this year has been the doubling of EU carbon prices, imposed to force fossil fuels out of the markets in favour of renewable energy. UK carbon prices have followed suit. As coal has the highest carbon footprint, thermal generation has switched from coal to gas, increasing demand for the latter, which is already in short supply. Gas generation capacity has not increased in either the EU or the UK in the past decade. Next year Germany will close all its nuclear power plants, further exacerbating electricity production.

Unless there is a mild winter and/or ease in demand, European utilities will be forced to look for alternative sources of energy (i.e., coal, not renewables).

High gas prices in the UK forced most of the country’s commercial production of carbon dioxide to shut down. This CO is a by-product of fertilizer manufacturing, which uses natural gas as a feedstock, and is critical to the production and transport of a range of products, from meat to bread, beer, and carbonated drinks.

The soaring natural gas prices have compelled utilities to run coal-fired power stations in order to keep the lights on. Drax, which owns the UK’s biggest facility, had planned to switch from coal to biomass this year, but will now extend the use of coal. This could complicate Britain’s plans to scrap all coal-powered generation by October 2024.

The non-ferrous metals industry association Eurometaux warns that rising power prices could lead to member companies moving their operations away from Europe. This would undermine the EU's carbon-cutting plans. In a letter addressed to Kadri Simson, European Commissioner for Energy, Eurometaux wrote: "Rising electricity prices have already led to curtailments and could lead to further relocation of our sector outside Europe if not addressed. We are also concerned that if electricity remains too expensive, it will disincentivize industrial electrification as a decarbonization route, undermining the EU’s Green Deal objectives."

Non-ferrous metals such as aluminum, copper, nickel and silicon are more electricity-intensive to produce than any other material. They will be needed to supply Green Deal items such as batteries, electric vehicles, wind turbines, solar panels and grid infrastructure.

Australia Shaping Up to Be the Villain of COP26

• The spatial (land and sea) requirements for wind and solar energy versus nuclear energy in two EU member states”? the Netherlands (a country along the North Sea with abundant wind) and the Czech Republic (a landlocked country with a geographically more challenging landscape).

Will the Green Economy Trigger the Next Crash?

Financier Bill Blain learned a painful lesson from the 2008 financial crisis, when a small but very significant part of the asset-backed securities market failed and shook markets to the core — like a few snowflakes triggering an avalanche. While Mr. Blain absolutely believes that climate change is the biggest challenge that humanity faces, he fears that the drive for renewable energy, especially wind, will trigger the next financial crash. The UK government has promoted wind power with messages that it's nearly costless and the country will be getting most of its energy in a few years’ time from abundant wind. Wind farms have proven to be popular, low-risk investments.

However, Mr. Blain points to a report, The Costs of Offshore Wind Power: Blindness and Insight, by John Constable and Prof. Gordon Hughes, that debunks the political, media and conversational cliché about dramatically falling prices of renewables. In fact, audited reports have found that wind power is becoming more expensive. Capital costs for new wind farms increased from 2002 to 2015 and have, at best remained constant since then. Operating costs have increased significantly for offshore and onshore wind farms over the past two decades as the inferior reliability of newer wind turbines leads to more rapid decline in performance with age.

The combination of increasing operating costs and decline in yields due to ageing means that, after expiry of the current above market-price contracts, means that expected revenues will be less than the costs. This will have consequences for financial regulation, eventually leading to a bailout of those who finance wind power. The scale of the bailout would be £30 billion for the UK and significantly more for Germany, the Netherlands and Denmark.

On December 22 Norway’s Supreme Court ruled not to overturn the Norwegian government’s approval of new licenses for offshore oil drilling in the fragile Arctic region. This ruling culminated four years of high-profile litigation, known as Greenpeace Nordic Association v. Ministry of Petroleum and Energy, The case started in Oslo District Court in October 2016 when a coalition of environmental groups (Young Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace, together with the Grandparents Climate Campaign and Friends of the Earth Norway) challenged the government's issuing of a block of oil and gas licenses for deep sea extraction from sites in the Barents Sea.

The petitioners argued that allowing access to these fossil fuel deposits is inconsistent with climate change mitigation, that there would be risks of damage and spills, and that the government would recoup its costs only if the oil and gas produced is sold are market prices. They relied on Article 112 of the Norwegian Constitution, which establishes a “right to an environment that is conducive to health and to a natural environment whose productivity and diversity are maintained.”?

In January 2018 the Oslo District Court ruled in favor of the Norwegian Government, declaring that emissions of CO from exported oil and gas are irrelevant in terms or Article 112. The petitioners appealed and lost again when, in January 2020, the Borgarting Court of Appeal upheld the District Court's ruling regarding the licenses and ruled that Article 112 does apply to emissions from oil and gas after export, but found there is uncertainty whether and to what extent the licenses will lead to increased greenhouse gas emissions. The Supreme Court ruled that future emissions from exported oil are too uncertain to bar the granting of the licenses.

How the Race for Renewables is Burning Europe's Forests

The Guardian is appalled by the misuse of taxpayer subsidies to destroy Europe's forests in order to produce "renewable" energy. About half of Estonia is covered with forests, these forests are threatened by EU-subsidized clear cutting to produce wood pellets for heat and power. Between 2001 and 2019 supposedly protected "Natura 2000" areas lost more than 15,000 hectares of forest cover, 80% in the past five years.

Burning wood appears to offer a simple and theoretically carbon-neutral alternative to coal-fired power because the trees take up CO as they grow, but the burning wood releases more CO per unit of energy than gas, oil or even coal. Moreover, replacing the carbon emitted by regrowing the trees takes decades. A flaw in the EU's energy directive categorizes woody biomass as fully renewable, whether woody residues, waste, or whole trees. This means that companies can directly harvest forests for pellets – rather than making pellets from the by-products of timber cut for other uses – in the name of sustainable forest management. Almost all European countries have recorded an increase in logging for energy. Nearly a quarter of the trees harvested in the EU in 2019 were for energy, up from 17% in 2000.
